label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 7, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, lamenting the heat that accompanies the mandatory blackout, discussing business affairs of Medway Plantation, and describing a near disaster he experienced while surfing. Sidney continues in his letter to recount the events of a cocktail party they attended at the officers club.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 7, 1943
Dear Gertie,
I have dated this letter the seventh because it will
be mailed then, but I am writing it on the evening of the sixth
in my apartment. It is as hot and as smelly as a bear pit with
the black out curtains shut and the perspiration is streaming down
my body. It is difficult to know whtehr it is better to go outside
and sit in the darkness and realtive coolness and be unable to
read or to sit insdie in a hemetically sealed room and suffer.
Perhaps if one read books about the artic and looked at pictures 
of ships encased in ice it would help. Soon you will be enveloped
in the heat of Washington vith that heavy damp depressing air
that saps ones vitality and tunrs every movement into a shower
of perspiration. I do hope you will be able to escape it
somehow, either by becoming a Waac or obtaining a position abroad
or at least out of that torrid city.
I received a letter from Miss Finucan in which she
said she did not understand why I had not received her letters
with my accounts and that they must have been lost. She also
said that she was houndlng Mr Anderson to make out my income tax,
statement. Considering that he had the federal tax made out from
the Guaranty Trust income statement for the Federal Government
I cannot understand what he is doing. It recalls t he slothfulness
of the South and their habit of going fishing when there is work
to be done. When you speak of living in tha country on a farm
after the war I have my doubts. It is very difficult to know
what will happen and I think only time will be able to solve the
problem. There will be the matter of xxxxxx finance, the question
of whether one wishes to live in the country away from people without
going to pieces mentaly, and the problem of the daily unproductive
grind of a farm without any of the equ lizing pleasures that are
obtainable in other forms of life. Still I must admit that the
sight of a plowed field gives me a thrill, and the cane growing in
straight lines , marching down the black soil is very exciting.
Morris has been feeling very badly for the past two weeks
and has gone to bed as soon as we reached home. As a resutt he has
been getting worse. Tonight I dragged him out surfboarding and
started him off on vitamins again which I found out he had dropped
when he was feeling well. xxxxxxx Now he is in bed reading and
feeling a great deal better so I think the worst is past and that
hs will soon be feeling hale and happy again.
[End Page 1]
The waves were enormous this evening. Duke Kahanmoko was out
on his Australian surf boat, a tiny thing th t looks l ke a
Kyak. He was marvellous, starting himself off with a paddle and
then leaping to his feet the picture of grace and south sea island
charm as he rode the crested foamers in. I caught one wave, a
monster and was slid ng down its side at a terrif_ic rate of speed
the bow going pit-a-pat, pit-a-pat as it bounced along, the edge
of the board cutting the water making a ho[l]low whishing sound[,]when
suddenly in fron[T] [scratched through] not more than four feet apart I saw two boards
with men on them. It was to late to dive into the water and
let my board jump them so I prayed to God and tried so steer between.
In a smother of spray and roaring xxxxx wave I zipped between
with only a half caught glimpse of their wide eyed frightened
faces. I couldnot have missed either of them by more than six inches
and had I hit going at that speed I certainly would have killed
someone. I was so xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx after I had
passed that I fell off and did not dare come up for at least half
a minute in fear of having hit xxxxxxx.them with the tail of the
board which veered at the last moment as unintenionaly I threw
my weigh to one side.
Roddy Wanamaker gave a cocktail party at the officers
club this afternobn and very kindly asked us, but we we e so late
leaving the office, and felt so dirty that we did not go. Anyway
there is something so futile about the idea of a coctail party
at the officers club, there being nothing to do but get drunk with
no place to go and only the next days work looming ahead like the .
sword of fate ready to fall at eight all hang over or no hang over.
Swimming and surfing are the only things that are fun and Morris
and I have only been to the officers club four times since we have
been out here, and that waseight months on the first of may.
Much water has run over and under the bridge since than and I feel
I have forgotten a great deal and possibly learned a very little,
if any,,about human nature and my job. Tennis is a thing of the
past, a golf club would be as strange to my hands as a pair of
reins. and my chief ambition is to lie down and sleep for twenty
four hours without ever waking up.
The af[r]ican war seems to be going better, but in my
own mind I do not confuse the African war and its winning with
the war on the continent and the defeat of Germany. The two are
years apart. While, the Pacific war is only in its infancy.
Hqwever by 1947 we should be well on our way to vicotry.
Goodbye dear, I send you all my love.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
